Speaker: larry
Dialogue: We're there.

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: Which apartment? Which apartment?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Move back. Where's the stairs? 5A.

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: Oh Jesus, it's Mr. Burke.

Speaker: john
Dialogue: We were just watching TV and Dad yelled out and started punching his chest, next thing he locked himself in the bathroom. I said we were gonna call you guys and he said not to. He was crying, I never heard him crying before, then he sorta stopped. We pulled him out and put him on the bed.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: How long ago did he stop breathing?

Speaker: john
Dialogue: Maybe ten minutes. Woman on the phone tried to tell us how to do CPR. Please, you gotta do something.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: We'll do all we can.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No more, please don't!

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Music. I think it helps if you play something he liked.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: John, play the Sinatra.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Play the Sinatra.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: It's OK, Frank. We can call it. Eighty- three.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No we can't. He's got a pulse.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: No shit.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Is he going to be alright?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: His heart's beating.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Help your family. Ride with your mother and brother.  Help your family. They need you more. Help yourself.

Speaker: griss
Dialogue: Hey partner. Your man does not look well. They're not gonna appreciate you inside.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Griss, let us in.

Speaker: griss
Dialogue: Things are backing up.

Speaker: nurse constance
Dialogue: Just keep moving. Don't even slow down.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: For God's sake, give me some water.

Speaker: big feet
Dialogue: Shut up! Goddamn civilians.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Give me some water!

Speaker: nurse crupp
Dialogue: Don't take another step. We're on diversion. Can't accept any more patients. Your dispatcher should have told you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: We got him at Eighteen and Second. You're closest.

Speaker: nurse crupp
Dialogue: Where will I put him, Frank? Look. Tell me.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He wanted to come here. Said the nurses at Misery were the best.

Speaker: nurse crupp
Dialogue: All right, give me a minute. I'll kick someone out of slot three.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Excuse me. You are a very kind man. I can see that. A man like you could not refuse a poor sick dying helpless man a small cup of water.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I can't. I have to stay with my patient.

Speaker: big feet
Dialogue: Shut the fuck up! If it wasn't for these dun feet I'd get up and kick your ass!

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: Godammit, guys, what are you doing to me? We're all backed up in here. Christ, would you look at him? He's gonna need the works. What's wrong with him?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You should know. You pronounced him.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: You told me he was dead. Flatline.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He got better.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: I hate pronouncing people dead over the phone.  Better, huh? They're fixed and dilated. He's plant food.

Speaker: nurse crupp
Dialogue: We stole a stretcher from X-ray. No pad on it, but I don't think he'll mind. Put him in three, next to the overdose.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: He's our lowest priority now. He shouldn't even be here. All this technology. What a waste.

Speaker: griss
Dialogue: Please folks, step back.  Don't make me take off my sunglasses.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: First-time heart attack, age 45. Should have gone to the CCU ten hours ago. There's three bodies up there Mike the one you just brought in. over there, two AIDS patients, one in twelve filling up with liquid. I'm gonna hafta intubate because the kid's mother won't sign the Do Not Resuscitate. Mercy killing doesn't translate well in Spanish. It's a sin to tube this kid. Three more ODs from some new killer junk. They call it Red Death.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Water, water, water, doctor man, water.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: A mix of heroin and I don't know what else, some kind of amino acid maybe. Stuff so strong they're drinking it with grain alcohol. You have to use ten times the usual amount of Narcan and watch out when they wake up, liable to go nuts on you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He one of them?

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: No, that's Noel. Used to be a regular off and on, hasn't been in in a while. He seized and almost coded--I gave him a hypertonic solution. He drank so much the kidneys were taking out salt. One for the textbooks.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Oh doctor, you are the greatest. You must help me.

Speaker: big feet
Dialogue: For God's sake, give him a drink of water.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: I am helping you, Noel. You could die if you drink more water.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Bless you sir, bless you.

Speaker: big feet
Dialogue: Shut up.

Speaker: nurse constance
Dialogue: ... so you get drunk every day and you fall down. Tell me why we should help you when you're going to get drunk tomorrow and fall down again?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He's very very sick.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I know him. That's Noel.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: We'd better go outside. Quickly.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Is there any chance?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I guess there's always a chance.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Noel, Noel, it's me, Mary. From 17th Street.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Mary, Mary, Mary. I'm so thirsty. They won't give me anything to drink. Please, Mary.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'll get you some.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I wouldn't do that.  The doctor seems to think he's suffering from some rare disorder.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It's not so rare. He grew up on our street. He's had a rough life and he's a little crazy from it, but that's no excuse for not giving someone a lousy cup of water.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Oh Mary, Mary, Mary.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: The Chinese close in five minutes. Beef lo mein. It's  been on my mind since I woke. Whatjathink?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I think the moment that food hits your mouth we'll get a job.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Turn here. You missed it. The Chink is on 3rd.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Some partner you are Frank. I coulda walked there faster. I'm starving and you stop to talk to hookers. You're making me nuts. Is that what you're trying to do, drag me down with you to nutsville?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: I'm so stupid. I had beef lo mein last night. I can't eat the same thing two nights in a row. It's almost two o'clock, what the hell am I gonna do? What you getting?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm not hungry.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Oh yeah, you don't eat food.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I eat. I just haven't had coffee yet.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Coffee and whiskey, lucky you ain't dead with that diet. Wait, I've got it. Half fried chicken with fries. Let's go, hurry up. Come on.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Turn it off.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You know what. The radio.

Speaker: police dispatch
Dialogue: Ladder Four, respond to a 10-22 four flight residential, 317 East 32nd.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Let's do it. It might be a good one.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You wanted it turned off. There's no such thing as a good fire. People get burned up. They can't breathe.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: That's what we're here for. Come on, Frank.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Don't push it, Larry.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You're burned out.

Speaker: radio dispatcher
Dialogue: One-three Zebra. Zebra three, I need you.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You see, he's giving it to us anyway.

Speaker: radio dispatcher
Dialogue: Zebra, are you there? I'm holding an unconscious at First and St. Marks.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: No! It's three o'clock. That can only mean one thing.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Mr. Oh.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: It's Mr. Oh. I'm not answering it.

Speaker: radio dispatcher
Dialogue: Answer the radio Zebra. You know it's that time.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Four times this week I've had him. Aren't there any other units out there?  Don't answer the radio. They'll give it to someone else.

Speaker: radio dispatcher
Dialogue: Thirteen Zebra. One-Three Zebra. You're going out of service in two seconds.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Look, Frank, when I say don't answer it, that means answer it.  Three Zebra.

Speaker: radio dispatcher
Dialogue: Yes, Zebra. You'll be driving to the man who needs no introduction, chronic caller of the year three straight and shooting for number four. The duke of drunk, the king of stink, our most frequent flier, Mr. Oh.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Ten-four.  Don't go. Not this time.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Relax, it's a street job, easy except for the smell. We'll just throw him in back and zip over to Mercy--no blood, no dying, that's how I look at it. He's just a drunk.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: It's not our job to taxi drunks around.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: They'll just keep calling.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Someone's gonna die someday causa that bum, going to have a cardiac and the only medics will be taking care of Mr. Oh.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: So what's different?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well why didn't you say so?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: He's drunk.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: He's fine. He can walk to the hospital.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Don't start that. I've seen him walk. He walks better than me.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: That's him, Mr. Oh.  Get up.

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: Good luck! Get better!

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Faster! God!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Faster!

Speaker: griss
Dialogue: Get that stinky-assed motherfucking bug-ridden skell out of my face.

Speaker: nurse constance
Dialogue: I would have to register you to give you something to eat and my conscience just will not allow that. Griss, the gentleman wants to leave.  He looks pale. You're not eating enough. You need more fiber.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: He's wasted. That's my diagnosis: shit-faced.

Speaker: nurse constance
Dialogue: He just needs a bath and some food. Take him in back and see if you can find a stretcher.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: She's nuts. That's why he comes here. She encourages him.

Speaker: nurse crupp
Dialogue: Don't you dare! That's my last stretcher. This is not a homeless shelter. He'll have to wait in the lobby.

Speaker: griss
Dialogue: No way man. Not even in the corner. Griss cannot abide the funk tonight.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It's my first cigarette in over a year.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: The first is always the best.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It's the waiting that's killing me, not knowing, you know? It's really hard on my mother. The doctor doesn't think my father'll make it. He says he was dead too long, after six minutes the brain starts to die and once that goes, close the door.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You never know.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I mean if he was dead, I could handle that.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: At least he's got people around him.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'm not so sure. My father and I haven't spoken in three years. When my brother called to say my father was having a heart attack, that he'd locked himself in the bathroom, all the way going over I was thinking how I was gonna tell him what a bastard he was. Then when I got up the stairs and we moved him onto the bed, I thought of all these other things I wanted to say.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Even when you say the things, there's always more things.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Right now, I'm more worried about my mother than anything. They won't let her see my father.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Go home. Take her home. Get some rest. Not going to find anything out now.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: That's what I told her. If she could just see him a second, then I could take her home.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Time to switch. I wheel, you heal.

Speaker: radio dispatcher
Dialogue: 12 David on the corner of Thirty- eight and Two you'll find a three- car accident, two taxis and a taxi. One-two Henry, 427 East Two-two, report of a very bad smell. No further information ...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Larry, swing over on Eighth. We're gonna hafta run one of these calls.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Relax, will you.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You have no sick time, Frank. No time of any kind. Everyone knows that.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Take me back, put me to bed; I surrender. We've done enough damage tonight.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You take things too seriously. Look at us, we're cruising around, talking, taking some quiet time, getting paid for it. We've got a good job here.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yeah, you're right.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Tell me, you ever think of doing anything else?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Sure, I'm taking the captain's exam next year. After the kids are in school, Louise can go back to the post office and, I thought, what the hell, I'll start my own medic service. Out on the Island the volunteers are becoming salaried municipal. It's just a matter of time and who you know. Someday it's going to be Chief Larry calling the shots.

Speaker: radio dispatcher
Dialogue: Zebra. One-three Zebra.  Zebra, answer the radio. Come on, I've got one for you. Pick up the radio and push the button on the side and speak into the front.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Zebra.

Speaker: radio dispatcher
Dialogue: Male bleeding, corner of Houston and One. No further information.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Ten-four.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Kill me!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Noel, don't!

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: He's crazy.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You really think so?

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: See, I can't do it. I came out of the desert.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You came out of the hospital. You were tied down and hallucinating. You got some bad chemicals in your head, Noel. There's some medicine at the hospital that will fix that.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: No, no medicine!

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: He got you.

Speaker: black punk
Dialogue: Do it! Man wants to die. Take him out! I know how to kill that mother.  Pop, pop.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Noel, you didn't let me finish. We have rules against killing people on the street. Looks bad, but there's a special room at the hospital for terminating. A nice quiet room with a big bed.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Oh man, do you mean that?  Thank you man, thank you. How?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, you have your choice: pills, injection, gas.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: I think pills. Yes, pills, definitely.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Jesus, Tom Walls, that crazy motherfucker.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Used to be my partner.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Frank, this the guy you called about? I know him.  You give my friend here any trouble and I'll kill you.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Yes, at the hospital.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: This looks like a very bad man I took in a couple weeks ago, a man who'd been holding two priests hostage with a screwdriver. I told him if I ever caught him making trouble again I'd kick the murdering life outta him.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's not worth it, Tom. He's surrendering.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: No prisoners. Don't worry, Frank, just a little psychological first aid.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Don't do it, Tom!

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: There's a double shooting three blocks- up. First and Third. confirmed.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: We'll do it.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: At the hospital. You told me at the hospital.

Speaker: bystander
Dialogue: Man just walked up and shot 'em. Not a word. Man, that was cold.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Where you hit?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Major Tom, I'm going to Misery. You take yours to Bellvue.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You're gonna feel a stick in your arm. Don't move.

Speaker: drug dealer
Dialogue: I don't want to die.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: I want to die. I'm the one.

Speaker: drug dealer
Dialogue: Oh Jesus, I don't want to die.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You're not going to die.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: What did you say?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Shut up. You're going to die and he's not. Got it.

Speaker: drug dealer
Dialogue: Hold my hand.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I can't. I got to do the other arm.

Speaker: drug dealer
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Hold this--right there. If you let go, I swear, I won't kill you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's all right. We're here.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Noel, let's go.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He's not breathing. Call a code.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Hello again.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's okay. They're prescription.  Works better with a little whiskey.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: That's my brother's problem. He's passed out inside.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: That's it! I can't do it anymore!

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: That boy you brought in, he was shot, wasn't he?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: He's dead, huh?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I think this place stinks.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Our Lady of Misery.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Did you see my father?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: It's crazy in there. What's wrong with that doctor? He keeps mumbling, poking himself in the eye when he talks to me.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He's working a double shift.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Thing is, I'm supposed to be the fuckup. The one on the stretcher in there--that's supposed to be me. With my parents crying out here. I got a lot of guilt, you know what I mean?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: She should go home.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'd take her, but then who would stay here?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Here she is.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You saw him?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Mrs. Burke, please, they'll take care of him. You should go home now.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Larry and I'll drop her back home. Help me get her to the ambulance.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Good morning, Captain.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm sick. That's what I've been telling you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's okay. I'll just get my things out of the locker.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm sorry Captain. Don't take it too hard.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You know they won't do it. It's up to you. You gotta be strong.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You swore you'd fire me if I came in late again.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I don't think a week's gonna do it.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: My Lord mother man, you look like hell. What were you drinking?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: The captain almost fired me tonight. I'm on my way out. Anytime now.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Nobody gets fired. Look at me. Only thing they might do is transfer you to the Bronx. You look like you aged ten years since I rode with you last.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: The ghosts--

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: You ever notice people who see shit always, are crazy?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I think the worst is over.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: It can always get worse. You can't change what's out there, only where you're coming from. You got to let the Lord take over, in here.

Speaker: dispatcher love
Dialogue: Twelve Young.  Let's go, Twelve Young. Answer the radio.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Hey, Marcus, it's Love. I haven't heard her in months.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: She only works when I'm on. I make her wait and it drives her crazy.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Is it true that you and Love went on a blind date?  She hit you with a bottle?

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: She loves me the way no woman ever has.

Speaker: dispatcher love
Dialogue: Twelve Young, I don't have time for your games. Now answer me or do I have to come out there myself?

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: I usually don't do calls before coffee. But I think it might do you some good.  Twelve Young is here and I'm gonna take care of you, baby. Don't you worry about a thing, yahear, cause Marcus is alive and on arrival.

Speaker: dispatcher love
Dialogue: I'm not your baby, Young, I'm not your mother either. You're going to a cardiac arrest, Avenue C and Ninth, northeast corner. It's a club. Take the side entrance.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Ten-four, hon.  This is for you.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: I hope we're not late from you guys holding us up here.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Okay, what happened?

Speaker: drummer
Dialogue: He's going to be all right, right?

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: No. He's dead.

Speaker: drummer
Dialogue: No way, man.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: He's dead and there's nothing we can do. Come on, Frank, that's it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He's not dead. It's a heroin overdose. Break out the Narcon.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: He's dead unless you folks want to stop bullshitting me and tell it straight. Then, Lord willing, we'll try to bring him back.

Speaker: bystander
Dialogue: He broke up with his old lady.

Speaker: girlfriend
Dialogue: We didn't break up. We were just seeing other people.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: I'm still waiting and this young man is still dead.

Speaker: bystander
Dialogue: She broke his heart.

Speaker: drummer
Dialogue: All right, all right, he's been snorting that Red Death stuff. Been going for four days.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: What's his name?

Speaker: drummer
Dialogue: IB Bangin.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: What'd you mean IB Bangin? What kind of name is IB Bangin?

Speaker: girlfriend
Dialogue: It's Frederick. Frederick Smith.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Okay, Freddy.

Speaker: girlfriend
Dialogue: It's Frederick.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Okay, IB Bangin, we're gonna bring you back. Every person here grab the hand of the person next to you.

Speaker: girlfriend
Dialogue: Frederick!

Speaker: bystander
Dialogue: Oh wow, man. Oh wow.

Speaker: ib bangin
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: girlfriend
Dialogue: You died, you stupid bastard. I warned you.

Speaker: drummer
Dialogue: You guys are awesome.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: C'mon.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Not us. The first step is Love. The second is Mercy.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: That guy I brought in yesterday, post-cardiac arrest. He's gone.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: Burke. You won't believe it. He's showing cognitive signs. He started with spontaneous respiration, now he's fighting to pull out the tube. Had to sedate him. He's in a CAT scan. I'm giving him every test I can: thromboytics, steroids, nitrodrips, heparin.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: Who knows? It's all lower-brain-stem- activity. The heart refuses to stabilize--he's coded eleven times since he got here. This guy's a fighter. Every time the Valium wears off he starts yanking those restraints.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: The family know?

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: I wanted to bring them in, to see if he'd respond to voices, but they weren't in the waiting room. The guy's daughter was in my face all last night and when I finally have something positive to tell her, she's gone.

Speaker: nurse constance
Dialogue: ... you put poison in your veins and now that you're breathing again you can't wait to say thank you and go back to poison shopping. Well, since we saved your life, maybe you could do us a favor and stop breathing in another city next time ...

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: I ever tell you about the time years ago I was on this ledge uptown, trying to talk this psycho inside?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Where the guy jumped and you almost fell. No, you never told me that story.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: No, you never listened. I was going, man, if someone on high hadn't pulled me in. I had put all I had into saving this dumbass lowlife suicidal that when he went down, there was a part of me that wanted to go with him.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Make a left here. I want to stop.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'll be right back.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Hello, I'm Frank Pierce, from the ambulance last night. I brought your father into the hospital and I just learned some news.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, the doctor says he's showing some movement. It's still early, it might mean nothing, but I thought you'd want to know.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I knew. I sensed it when I heard your voice.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You look so different.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I know. It's awful, isn't it? Night of the Living Cheerleaders.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I think it looks good.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I was going nuts in that waiting room so I came back to check on my mom.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: How is she?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Sleeping.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I was just going to get some food. Pizza. Maybe we could.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You can't kill my father that easy. He'll fight forever. Like with me: hasn't talked to me in three years. But it's okay. Sometimes you have to put things behind you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Be tough to get a taxi here. We can give you a ride if you like.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Who's that?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: She's the daughter of a cardiac arrest I brought in last night. I told her we'd give her a ride back to Misery. Her father's showing signs of improving.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Oh, Frank, you've got it bad, so much worse than I thought.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm hungry too. We gotta get some food after this.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: God help us, he's hungry too.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Dad, can you hear me?  Open your eyes if you can hear me.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: I'll be damned.  It's movement, but I'm not sure how voluntary.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: He hears me. Open your eyes, Dad.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: Nurse Crupp, I need ten milligrams of Valium.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Why don't we go outside for a little while, wait until this passes.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He wants to pull that tube out. It's pretty painful--that's why they keep him sedated--but it's a good sign.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You sure? I know my father would hate to be tied down. He wouldn't even go to the dentist.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: That's how it's done. You have to keep the body going until the brain and heart recover enough to go on their own.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: He's better, though, right?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He's better.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Look, I'm sorry, but it's important to me. I mean, a week ago I was wishing he was dead. And now I want hear his voice again, just once more-- you know what I mean?

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Went over to Sal's got this. There must be some place in Hell for a guy who sells a dollar-fifty a slice. I call you if anything comes up.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'm not really hungry.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's best not to ...  It's good pizza, huh?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Not as good as Nino's.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You remember that pizza place, Joe's on Tenth Street maybe fifteen years ago?  When you ordered a pie it came with a little plastic madonna in the middle?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Yeah, or Saint Anthony. You from the neighborhood?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I grew up on Elizabeth. I went to Blessed Sacrament.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: On yeah? I went to Holy Name. Where'd you go to high school?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: We moved out after that. Upstate.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Like everybody else--except us. Always standing on the sidewalk waving goodbye to moving trucks. Your parents ... ?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: They're fine. My old man was a bus driver, mom a nurse--I was sort of born to it, I guess.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You married?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Ah, no. I was.  It's hard to explain. She had a hard time adjusting to, well, maybe it was my fault too.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Is it always this bad in here? I mean, how does anyone survive?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's been bad lately, but it's always bad.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: How long you been doing this?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Five years.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Wow, you musta seen some things, huh? What's the worst thing you ever seen?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You learn to sort of block it out, you know, like cops fence off a crime scene. But then something good will happen and everything will just glow.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You must get a lot of overdoses. I bet you picked me up a couple of times.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I think I'd remember that.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Maybe not. I was a different person then. Does everybody you meet spill their problems on you like this?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Mostly. It must be my face. My mother always said I looked like a priest.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I better go check on my father. Thanks for the pizza. I owe you one. Maybe when he gets better, you know, when we're done with all this.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Rule number one: Don't get involved with patients. Rule number two: Don't get involved with patient's daughters. You understand?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What about rule number three: Don't get involved with dispatchers named Love.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: You don't know the first thing about rule number three, cannot begin to understand the complexities of that rule. Come on, let's go look at some hookers. The Kit Kat will be letting out.  Don't ever call a junkie whore a crackhead. They get real mad.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: ... look at her. Leaves you no idea what's underneath, not even a suggestion. Could be a skeleton for all you know.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: She's no whore, Marcus.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: We're all whores, Frank. You know what I'm talking about, the way she looked at me.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: She wasn't looking at you, man, she was looking at me.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I didn't kill you.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: No, you didn't, Frank, thank you. But there's still a couple hours left on the shift.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I need a drink, that's all.

Speaker: dispatcher love
Dialogue: Twelve Young, answer the radio. I have a call for you.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: She said to me, I love the way you talk on the radio.

Speaker: dispatcher love
Dialogue: I can't wait all night, Young. I'm holding a priority and if you don't answer I'm going to knock you out of service.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Don't worry, hon. Young is here and he's gonna help out--just remember, you owe me.

Speaker: dispatcher love
Dialogue: You're going to three-four Avenue C, 17 year-old female cardiac arrest, no further information.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Ten-four, hon.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Look at that. A fat junkie. That's a first.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What's wrong.

Speaker: carlos
Dialogue: No English. She has terrible pain in her belly.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Pregnant.

Speaker: carlos
Dialogue: No, no, that's impossible.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Are you pregnant? Estas embarazada?

Speaker: carlos
Dialogue: She say she in great pain.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Thanks for the translation.  What's your name? Nombre?

Speaker: maria
Dialogue: Maria.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Let's have a look.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: You know each other a long time?

Speaker: carlos
Dialogue: Two years. Ever since we left island.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: In that time, you ever have sex?

Speaker: carlos
Dialogue: Never. No cigarettes, no drugs, no booze.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: No underwear?

Speaker: carlos
Dialogue: We are virgins.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Oh Jesus, we'd better go. Call for backup.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: What's that, Frank?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Three legs.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: That's too many.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Backup?

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: It's coming.

Speaker: carlos
Dialogue: Is she dying?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: She's having a baby. Twins.

Speaker: carlos
Dialogue: Es impossible.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You can trust me on this one.

Speaker: carlos
Dialogue: It's a miracle.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You take the first one.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: She had a pulse.

Speaker: nurse constance
Dialogue: Code! Code Blue!

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: Oh Jesus, put her on the monitor. Where's the pediatric code cart?  Odette give me that tube. All right, flatline--let's do CPR. step back, Frank. How many months?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Can't tell. It was a breech, twins. The other one seems okay, though. Marcus is taking him and the mother to Maternity.

Speaker: crackhead
Dialogue: I'm a mother! I got a daughter! I got rights!

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: 10 mil Valium, stat.

Speaker: mishra
Dialogue: Status.

Speaker: nurse constance
Dialogue: I think there's a pulse. I think.

Speaker: mishra
Dialogue: Fuck.

Speaker: nurse constance
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: noel
Dialogue: Excuse me, sir, excuse me, I would please trouble you for one cup of water. The smallest thing in the world to ask for, water. A man is dying and that is me.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: Christ. Who the hell woke him up?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Don't give me that look.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: What look?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You know what I'm talking about. It's all over your face. That I-just- saved-a-little-baby-boy look.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: We just saved a little baby boy. Think of it that way.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I don't want to hear about it, okay? That's three jobs for the night. It's over. Three jobs and time for a drink. Six am, the cocktail hour. Pass the bottle; I know you're holding.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: The bar is now open.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I hate vodka.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Please, a little decorum if you will. What I was going to say is, is that holding that baby in my arms, I felt like I was twenty-one again. A call like that makes me think of going back to three nights a week, not two, start running again, cut down on the drinking.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'll drink to that.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Here's to the greatest job in the world.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Greatest job in the world.

Speaker: dispatcher love
Dialogue: Twelve Young, I have priorities holding. Pick up the radio.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Don't do it, Marcus. Tell her the bus died, our radio's not working, our backs are out. Tell her we're too drunk to take any more calls.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Let's do it!  It's Marcus, Love, only for you.

Speaker: dispatcher love
Dialogue: Male diff breather, approximately 30, Houston and A.

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: Ten-four.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I quit! I'm through!

Speaker: marcus
Dialogue: You can't leave me now.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: So long, Noel.

Speaker: griss
Dialogue: Your friend there just untied the water beggar. Griss was coming out to thank her. Probably saved Griss a murder charge.  Having a tough time of it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Excuse me. You seemed like you were in trouble.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'm all right. I just can't stand to see people tied up.  I'm in the waiting room for hours, listening to Noel screaming. The only reason he's screaming is 'cause he's tied up.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Don't seem so bad to me.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Don't say that. I wanted to cut my father loose too. They told me he almost died and five minutes later they say he's better and I go in. It's killing me seeing him fighting like that.  Look, since you're here, maybe you could do me a favor. I need you to wait for me outside this building, okay? I have to visit a friend who's sick.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I'm only asking because it's a dangerous building. There's been some robberies, a woman was raped not long ago. This woman I'm seeing, she'll want to talk to me all day, but if I can point to you out the window and say you're waiting, I can be out quick. if anything happens, I'll be in apartment 16M.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Maybe I should come up with you.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: If I'm not back in fifteen minutes, hit the buzzer. That way she'll let me go.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Nothing's going to happen. I'll come with you.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No, I'll be fine. I'm just visiting a sick friend.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I shouldn't have asked you to come.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You asked me not to come.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Promise you won't go inside.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Fifteen minutes.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I just have to relax a little. Not feel so guilty all the time.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: We can still go back. I'll walk you home. You sleep a couple of hours, watch some TV, take a bath.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Don't be a cop. If you have any doubts about this, it's my fault.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You go on home, okay. I'm fine, really. I don't need you. Thanks.

Speaker: kanita
Dialogue: Hey Cy, guess who's here?

Speaker: kanita
Dialogue: Can I help you?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Mary Burke. She's a friend.

Speaker: kanita
Dialogue: She's not here.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: It's okay, Kanita. Come on in.

Speaker: kanita
Dialogue: He looks like a cop.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: He's not a cop, he's a medic.  I'm CY Coates.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Frank Pierce.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: Mary said you might be coming.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Where is she?

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: Sleeping in the back.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: She asked me to pick her up.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: I know, but she told me to tell you she wants to crash here a few hours. Terrible about her father, isn't it?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I better just go in and see her.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: I call this the Oasis. Refuge from the world out there. Did you know two people were shot in this building last week?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Mary. Mary, we've got to get going.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No, no.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: She wanted something to help her sleep.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Mary, we really have to go.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: Frank, she's suffered enough. She's okay, I promise.  C'mon, Frank.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Got a beer?

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: That shit is poison, Frank. We don't drink alcohol here. What you need is one of these.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Did you give Mary something called Red Death?

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: Red Death?  Tell me something, Frank--does killing your clients make good business sense to you? The kids selling that shit have no sense. They'll be taken care of, don't worry about that.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I should be going. I just quit.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: Sleep is all stress reduction. Here.  Why do you think I'm telling you this, Frank--for my health?  You ought to look at yourself in the mirror, man. Kanita, get him a glass of water.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Is this what you gave Mary?

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: That's the stuff. I call it the Red Lion. Very king-of-the-jungle.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I guess I'll be going.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: Just take it easy.

Speaker: kanita
Dialogue: Take my pulse.  It's good, isn't it?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Perfect.

Speaker: kanita
Dialogue: I knew it. I was wrong about you. You're not so bad.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You're in the stomach!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You sure?

Speaker: rose
Dialogue: Rose!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: rose
Dialogue: My name. Rose.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You're in the stomach, man.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: One more time!

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Stomach again.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No way!

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: Frank, take it easy. what happened?

Speaker: kanita
Dialogue: He flipped out.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: Be cool, man. You're having a paradoxical reaction. It can happen.  Didn't I tell you this guy was stressed out?

Speaker: kanita
Dialogue: Stressed? He's psycho.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: Frank, where you going?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I can walk.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Let go of me.  You shouldn't have come up. I told you not to. You could have gotten us both killed.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Because you can barely walk.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You remember Noel, from the other night, how Noel is now? He wasn't always like that. He was my brother's best friend. Cy or Tiger or one of those other goons put a bullet in Noel's head. He was in a coma three months. Crazy ever since.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: What is it? You want to help me, you feel sorry for me? Keep it to yourself.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I need to sit down a minute.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Or maybe you wanna fuck me? Everyone else has.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Hello, I'm Frank. Mary's friend. A very close friend who loves animals.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No ...

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What if there is no tomorrow?

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Frank, what do you know. It's you and me again tonight, the Rough Riders, tearing up the streets just like old times.  This old bus is a warrior, Frank, just like us. I have tried to kill him and he will not die. I have a great respect for that.

Speaker: griss
Dialogue: Don't make me take off my sunglasses.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Morning, Griss.

Speaker: nurse constance
Dialogue: We're full up tonight, Frank.

Speaker: burke's voice
Dialogue: Go to the bank, boy, take out everything you can.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Mr. Burke?

Speaker: burke's voice
Dialogue: I'm going. I've had enough.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You do it.

Speaker: milagros
Dialogue: Can't reach. You're taller.

Speaker: burke's voice
Dialogue: Don't do it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I thought he was getting better.

Speaker: milagros
Dialogue: Technically, yeah. I suppose. It doesn't matter.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: milagros
Dialogue: Tha family wants us to do everything to save him--so, that's it. They want to keep him alive, they want to believe in miracles, we keep him alive. Shock him, Frank. He'll come back. He always comes back.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Clear!

Speaker: burke's voice
Dialogue: Ow!

Speaker: milagros
Dialogue: Should I increase the lidocaine?

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Frank, what you doing back there?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm sick, Tom. I need a cure.  Vitamin B cocktail, followed by an amp of glucose and a drop of adrenaline. Not as good as beer, but all I got.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Come on, Frank. There's blood spilling in the streets.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: These are hard times, Tom.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Yeah. Great, isn't it?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Great to be drunk. Sobriety's killing me.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Look up, Frank. Full moon. The blood's gonna run tonight. I can feel it. Our mission: to save lives.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Our mission is coffee, Tom. A shot of the bull, Puerto Rican espresso.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Ten-four. El Toro de Oro. Blast off.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: The cure's not working, Tom. Maybe we should go back to the hospital.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Don't worry, kid. Tom'll take care of you. Put your head out the window, get some of that summer air. Listen to the music. El Toro de Oro. Andale. Pronto.

Speaker: dispatcher
Dialogue: Okay, units, it's suicide hour. Fourteen Boy, I show you in the hospital sixty minutes but I know you're in the diner on 14th. Put down the burger, I got a call for you around the corner, 14 and 3rd, a man with a noose around his neck and nothing to hang it on. Sixteen XRay, don't even think about getting coffee, I have a call for you too.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Sixteen XTerminator here. We like our coffee bloody. Make it good--my partner's dying to help someone.

Speaker: dispatcher
Dialogue: You're in luck, X: your patient awaits you with bleeding wrists on Avenue C and Fourth.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Tom, where are the Band-aids? This is an ambulance, isn't it?

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Look out!

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: What the hell's going on?

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Hold it. I will not take anyone anywhere against his will. This is America. People have rights.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: You're lucky you didn't kill him.  We're going to hear it straight from the loony's mouth. Are you crazy? Did you try to bump yourself off?

Speaker: cut wrists
Dialogue: Yesssss.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Why didn't you say so.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: This is the worst suicide attempt I've ever seen. You feel the pulse? Here. That's where you cut, and it's not across, it's down like so.  Here take it.

Speaker: cut wrists
Dialogue: I can't.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: With all the poor people of this city who wanted only to live and were viciously murdered, you have the nerve to sit here waiting to die and not go through with it. You make me sick. Take it.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: We cured him, Frank. When we work together there's nothing we can't fix.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Sounds like they're trying to clean up the bus terminal tonight,

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: C'mon, Tom. The city's burning.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Whatja doing?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I feel the need, the need for speed. I'm driving out of myself.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: The brakes are shot.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I've taken that into consideration.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I never felt better in my life.

Speaker: dispatcher
Dialogue: Sixteen XRay, XRay.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: X.

Speaker: dispatcher
Dialogue: First of all, I want you to know how sorry I am about this. I've always liked you two. A unit above none, a legend in its own lunchtime, so it hurts me deeply to do this but I have no choice. You must go to Second and St. Marks. In front of a liquor store you'll find a forty year-old male, unconscious, lying next to his wheelchair. Do I have to say more?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You've said too much already.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Mr. Oh.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's early for him.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: That's all right, we're not meant to do Oh tonight. Something is going to happen. I can feel it.

Speaker: police dispatch
Dialogue: A jumper. Stuyvesant Town.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Ten-four.   One minute out.

Speaker: dispatcher
Dialogue: Sixteen, Sixteen XRay. Level One Emergency.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Whadda we bring?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Better bring it all.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: The elevator's fucked. We'd never all fit anyway. Let's go.

Speaker: fireman
Dialogue: That's thirteen flights.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: The news guys just pulled up.

Speaker: police sergeant
Dialogue: The stairs, men, the stairs.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: This guy a jumper?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: We got a call for shots fired on the sixteenth floor. The jumper called right after.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm going to sixteen.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: That's it, nobody else home.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm going to thirteen.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Get this, Frank--we got two patients. Number one, the scarecrow outside. Number two misses the railing but breaks both legs on the balcony, then throws himself through a glass window, heads to the bedroom, where he's now passed out.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Well, he's the steakhead of the night, then.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: I don't think the fire people can touch him out there.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: How's he doing?

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: I haven't had a chance to see him yet. I'm going to take care of sleeping beauty.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Does that hurt?

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I don't think you've hurt any major organs.  We got to get you off this thing without setting off bleeding.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: I can't hold up my head anymore.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: You're going to live.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: I've been thinking about things. Meditating on my financial future. You guys gave me plenty of time to meditate on the future. Whatja do, stop for Chinese on the way over? There's plenty of food in my place.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I was tired. I needed a coffee.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: What about Kanita?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Dead.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: That's too bad. Get some money, a nice looking girl on your arm, and everyone wants to take a piece. Some kid I wouldn't let wash my Mercedes is in my house, shooting at me. Damn, I thought I could make it onto the balcony like Tiger. He's fat, that's why, falls faster. I'm trying to watch my weight, and look what happens. Am I shot, Frank?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: Boy can't shoot for shit, either. Goddamn that's hot.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Good thing we buckled you in, huh?

Speaker: coates
Dialogue: What about me? Who's supposed to buckle me?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: I thought you did.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: I'm so sorry, sir.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: Nurse Crupp, we're going to need some Valium here. He's waking up again.

Speaker: burke's voice
Dialogue: Don't. Don't do it.

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: Give me a hand, Frank. I've got to get something between those teeth.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: How many times have you shocked him tonight?

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: Fourteen. We finally got him a room upstairs. Should be up there in a couple of hours.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: What do you do, just have someone follow him around with a defribilator?

Speaker: hazmat
Dialogue: That's good, Frank. No, but they might surgically implant one, about the size of my thumb. It goes near the shoulder here, with two electrodes connected to the heart. It sends a shock whenever it senses a drop in blood flow. Amazing, isn't it?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: A medical miracle.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Everyone, this is the medic who brought my father in. Frank, these are some of my father's friends.

Speaker: family friend
Dialogue: We live out an the Island now, but we used to live right down the block from Pat. He was like a saint to us. Came as soon as we heard.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm going out for a smoke.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I heard CY Coates was brought in. He looked pretty bad.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: He'll be all right.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Too bad. He called me up today, can you believe that? I don't know how he got my number. He asks me do I want to come over and see him, I tell him I'd rather go to a leper colony. He says there's a new gang that wants to kill him, take over the business. I told him I hope he's right. That they kill him. That's what I told him.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It'll be a while before he's up and running again.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: OK, last night I was weak. it won't happen again. And all that shit I said--it was just because I was stoned. Forget it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No problem. Thanks for letting me crash. It was the best sleep I've had in months. I used some of your soap.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I wish these people would leave already. I can't listen to another story. Did you see him?  That doctor says the brain is coming around. They're waiting for the heart to stabilize. I don't know who to believe. He says they still have to keep him tied up.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Can I bring you something back to eat--a falafal, some pizza?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: No, we just ate. I only remember how tough my father was. Now I know he had to be like that, to make us tough. This city'll kill you if you aren't strong enough.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: No, the city doesn't discriminate. It gets everybody.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: This is not a good time.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: There's no time.

Speaker: walls
Dialogue: Get ready, Frank. Missed a drug shooting while you were dicking around in there. There's gonna be trauma tonight!
